item.title: Where to Find All New Gathering Materials in Final Fantasy 14: Dawntrail
item.description:
Quick Links

  • All New Cloth
  • All New Lumber
  • All New Ingredients
  • All New Stones

The Gathering System in Final Fantasy 14 is pretty fun for a lot of players. Items such as stones, lumber, cloth, and other items can all be obtained by going out into the world and gathering them or the ingredients for them.

Once they have been gathered, a lot of these items can be used as crafting items, which will let the Disciplines of the Hand create new items. In Dawntrail's Patch 7.0 update, several new items that are obtained via Gathering were added. Here's a list of them all.

These are just the materials we have found and ways that we have discovered to obtain these items. This list will be updated if there are other items and ways that are found.

All New Cloth

Here's all the new Cloth added. These can be obtained using Harvesting.

Item Name

How To Obtain

Blackseed Cotton Boll

  • Asyle Volcane
  • Living Memory

Levinsilk

  • Heritage Found
  • Everkeep Ward

Mountain Flax

  • Larh Tortoh
  • Urqopacha

Mountain Linen

  • Crafted

Rroneek Fleece

  • Hunting Venture

Rroneek Serge

  • Crafted
  • Levequests

Sarcenet

  • The Xobr'it Cinderfield
  • Yak T'el

Sarcenet Cloth

  • Crafted

Snow Cotton

  • Chabameki
  • Urqopacha

Snow Cotton Cloth

  • Crafted

Thunderyards Silk

  • Levequests

Timeless Turali

  • Loboskin Treasure Map

Here's all the new Lumber added. These can be obtained using Logging.

item.title: Valorant: Best Agent For Each Role On The Ascent Map
item.description:
Highlights

  • Ascent, an OG Valorant map, divides player opinions.
  • Jett reigns as the top primary duelist, while KAY/O thrives in the flex role on Ascent.
  • The agents on this list have abilities that contribute to site control, defense, and offense, making them crucial picks for Ascent.

Ascent is one of the OG maps in Valorant . It has been in the game since the release of the game. Ascent is one of the generic and simple maps currently in the game. The map consists of A-site, B-site and a dedicated mid where players can diverge to either of the sites.

In addition, it is also a map that the Valorant community is divided about. Some players love the simplicity of the map, while others complain about its lanes and paper-like walls. Nevertheless, players have to play Ascent when it shows up in the game and thus picking the right agent for their role is very crucial.

5 Killjoy

Role: Sentinel

Signature ability

Turret

Ultimate ability

Lockdown

Ultimate points

9

Sentinels are crucial to have in the team composition in Valorant . They help in anchoring the site easily while defending and help in watching the flanks when attacking. For the Ascent map, Killjoy does this job brilliantly. While defending, her setup, specifically for the B-site, is very strong. Killjoy can set up her turret toward the B main to check any push and place the Nanoswarms along with Alarmbot in the B-lane to deal tonnes of damage to enemies trying to break into the site.

In addition, her ultimate, Lockdown, is very strong for retaking sites. She also has great prowess when attacking. Her Turret is a brilliant flank watcher, and she can also place her Alarmbot to keep backstabbers in check. Her Nanoswarms provide a lot of value while playing post-plant. KJ can either place the Nanoswarms near the spike or use line-ups, which are more effective.

4 Omen

Role: Controller

Signature ability

Dark Cover

Ultimate ability

From the Shadows

Ultimate points

7

Omen is currently one of the most picked controllers overall in Valorant . Many pro players and top-tier players prefer playing Omen on Ascent other than other available controllers. His smokes are much easier to place on the map, and due to Omen's mechanics, he can smoke off contact points from far distances. In addition, there are multiple spots on Ascent where players can exploit Omen's smoke mechanics to create one-ways.

It will help to halt the push big time. His Shrouded Step ability helps with taking unexpected spots and catching enemies off-guard. His Paranoia ability is hard to dodge at a closer distance and is great for executing a push. His ultimate, From The Shadows, helps with fast rotation and can help a lot if the enemy's rotation is read correctly.

3 Sova

Role: Initiator

Signature ability

Recon Bolt

Ultimate ability

Hunter's Fury

Ultimate cost

8

Sova is the king of the initiator class in Valorant , and rightfully so. His kit provides so much value on Ascent that it is a missed opportunity to pick any other initiator instead of him. The best thing about Sova is that this agent is much easier to play and has such a high ceiling. A perfectly placed Recon Dart can reveal all enemies on the site and help to decide whether to execute the site or change the approach.

Since Ascent has multiple choke points and tight spaces, his dart is very valuable in scouting these spaces before approaching them. His dart on the Heaven pillar on the A-site can help scout 90% of the site. For B-site, the tree above the double boxes can be used. Since the walls of Ascent are paper thin, players can pair Recon Bolt with high-penetrating weapons such as Guardian, Odin, Operator, etc.

His Shock Dart is also a great tool to flush out enemies in the multiple choke points and tight spaces. These Shock Darts started the whole line-up approach in Valorant. Sova has very simple line-ups for both sites on Ascent to play on line-ups post-plant. His ultimate ability, Hunter's Fury, is great for clearing angles and halting defuses in the post-plant.

2 KAY/O

Role: Flex

Signature ability

Zero/point

Ultimate ability

Null/cmd

Ultimate cost

8

KAY/O is the most preferred agent for the flex role on Ascent. KAY/O is primarily an initiator agent in Valorant , though his prowess as the primary initiator on Ascent is limited. However, in the flex role, he provides a lot of value. His signature ability, Zero/Point, suppresses enemies in the radius and forces them to rely on their raw aim skills. With this, he can disrupt defensive setups of Sentinels for site executions. In addition, KAY/O has one of the unique flashes in the game.

He can use underhand flashes, similar to what players use in Counter Strike, for quick peeks. His high overhead flashes, especially on this map, are valuable for catching enemies off-guard. His Frag/Ment molly helps with flushing out enemies from tight spots, such as logs on B-site, Pizza in mid, and tree toward A-site. It is also valuable for post-plants by utilizing the line-ups. Frag/ment can also be used to halt pushes. His ultimate, Null/cmd, is probably one of the best ultimate in Valorant. Anyone in the 42.5-meter radius will be suppressed and provided an enhanced fire rate and reload rate to KAY/O. It just makes entering sites and re-taking sites from enemies a lot easier.

1 Jett

Role: Duelist

Signature ability

Tailwind

Ultimate ability

Blade Storm

Ultimate cost

8

Jett is the undisputed top pick for the primary duelist on Ascent. Her ability to break into sites easily and disrupt the aims of enemies is unparalleled. Her Tailwind and Cloudburst combo is as great as peanut butter and jam. She can use Cloudburst to smoke out of spots and dash in to take spots.

The most commonly used is in the B main with smoking the switch in workshop and dashing there while checking logs to close the market gate. On A-site, her Tailwind, Cloudburst and Updraft combo is primarily used to get to the top of the generator. Ascent has multiple straight lanes where Jett can use the operator to get a lot of value.

Mid primarily is the place where most of the sniping takes place. The Blade Storm ultimate ability is the best offensive ults in Valorant. It is free of any movement errors, and Jett can just Updraft, dash, and run through enemies while popping enemy heads easily. The best thing is that it lets Jett players manage their economy and save for better weapons in the next round.

item.title: Disney Dreamlight Valley: How to Get Wrought Iron
item.description:
Disney Dreamlight Valley is an adventure life sim where players get to live in a magical valley with many popular Disney and Pixar characters. As you play the game, you can make friends with those characters, do interesting quests, explore their realms, and build and customize your valley.

With each update, Gameloft adds new quests, Star Path duties, and special materials to the game. The recent update, The Lucky Dragon, introduced a new crafting material called Wrought Iron, which you can use to make lots of different items in the game. Below, we’ll cover everything you need to know about Wrought Iron in Disney Dreamlight Valley.

How to Get Wrought Iron in Disney Dreamlight Valley

Wrought Iron is a rare material you can get from Remy – the cute little chef from Ratatouille. It’s only available to players who have The Lucky Dragon update. And yes, Wrought Iron is different from Iron Ingot and Iron Ore.

To get Wrought Iron, Dreamers will have to complete the Bon Appetit quest. As its name suggests, it’s a food-related quest in which Remy asks you to cook delicious meals daily and serve them to customers in the Chez Remy restaurant. Once you do that, you will get your hands on Wrought Iron.

On the first day, Remy will ask you to make and deliver the following meals:

  • A meal with Slush Ice for Elsa
  • A dessert for Belle
  • A fish meal for Nala
  • A 5-star meal for Ariel.

In return, you'll get six Wrought Iron pieces. Furthermore, he wants you to craft some furniture items for the restaurant using this material. Once you do that, he will give you three more Wrought Iron pieces and ask you to come every day for more tasks and rewards. Each day, you'll get a new delivery task, and you'll get more Wrought Iron as you serve and craft furniture items.

How to Use Wrought Iron in DDV

Wrought Iron in Disney Dreamlight Valley is used to make different furniture items. You can craft things like chairs, tables, and fences, which you can use to decorate Remy’s restaurant.

Here is a list of items you can craft using Wrought Iron:

  • Parisian Chair
  • Ornate Parisian Chair
  • Parisian Table
  • Ornate Parisian Table
  • Ornate Parisian Statue
  • Wrought Iron Walkway Slab
  • Wrought Iron Fence

After you create them, you can place these chairs, tables, statues, and other decorative items outside Chez Remy restaurant in the Plaza.

item.title: Where to Find All New Crafting Materials in Final Fantasy 14: Dawntrail
item.description:
Quick Links

  • All New Cloth
  • All New Leather
  • All New Lumber
  • All New Metal
  • All New Reagents
  • All New Stones

Final Fantasy 14 is Square Enix's MMO for the Final Fantasy franchise, and it has been a massive hit since it came out. The game has had many expansions by now, and with the Dawntrail Expansion and Patch 7.0, the game added a ton of new crafting materials.

These materials can be used by the Disciplines of the Hand to craft new items. While some of the new crafting items can be made by Disciplines of the Hand (and some are part of the new crafter quests), Disciplines of the Land are also needed to gather most of the materials (which can be part of the new gatherer quests). Here's a list of them all.

These are all the items and ways that we have found to obtain these new materials. This will be updated if more ways are found for each item.

All New Cloth

Here's all the new Cloth added. These can be obtained using Harvesting.

item.title: 10 Great JRPGs That Can Feel Like They Are Too Long
item.description:
The JRPG genre has tons of great qualities that distinguish it from regular RPGs. Chief among them are non-traditional storytelling and impactful characters. Their aesthetic reflects the popular manga/anime culture of Japan, and they are faithful to their traditional animation standards. However, there are times when a great game can go on for hours, making players lose track of time. Sometimes, players can get stuck in an endless loop of secondary routes, or dialogues between characters that have a lot to say about the world they live in.

The following titles are filled with great gameplay and characters, but they might be considered too long for normal standards. From never-ending dialogue cutscenes and chatty villains to incredibly well-hidden secrets, these JRPGs are worth their weight in gameplay hours. That said, completionists be warned: These games require patience and dedication to reach 100%.

Tales Of Berseria

Vengeance That Takes Far Too Long To Fulfill

Tales of Berseria narrates the journey of Velvet Crowe and her merry group of allies in her quest for vengeance through the land of Midgand. Velvet is looking for the man who murdered her brother. She’s also a demoneater, a being capable of absorbing the powers of Hellions/Daemons alongside their memories.

The gameplay is great, and the characters are colorful and well-written. However, the plot doesn’t integrate well with each of the characters’ “mission in the world.” This dilutes the main storyline until the player loses track of what began as a quest for vengeance.

Chrono Cross

Spend Years Unlocking All The Characters

Chrono Cross is a timeless masterpiece and a must-play for every lover of the JRPG genre. The curious thing about this game is that its world is so big and colorful that even today, even the most hardcore players doubt they have unlocked all the available content.

Depending on the choices players make, or which characters they recruit for their journey, they might miss some other characters that get locked, or not meet the conditions to recruit them. It is a beautiful mess, guaranteed to take thousands of hours of gameplay to complete it all. But, the question remains: Have all available characters been discovered?

Final Fantasy 13

Great Gameplay With A Vast World & Slow Plot

Final Fantasy 13 and its sequels revolutionized the FF core gameplay and visual engine. It is an overall great experience with incredibly dynamic combat. But sadly, the same cannot be said about its storyline.

FFXIII starts hard and fast, packed with action, only to be diluted by unnecessary dialogue, forced enmity between the main characters, and a plot that never fully takes shape. Even when the expansions shed some light on the events of the first game, this only delays the resolution of the plot. Eventually, it becomes too long for the average player to understand to its fullest. It's necessary play Final Fantasy XIII-2 and Lightning Returns to appreciate the plot in its whole, but for gamers who have the time, it is worth playing.

Tales of Zestiria

Getting The Good Endings Takes Too Long

This game has it all: great plot, characters, gameplay, fun, and a cool villain. All those things compose Tales of Zestiria , a visually spectacular JPRG. It is technically the sequel of Tales of Berseria, but was released before Velvet Crowe’s story.

What makes this JRPG such a long and tiring journey, is that several bad endings are lurking early during the adventure. Stumbling across them is all too easy. To reach the good ending of this story, players need to put in a whopping 120+ hours of gameplay. It’s excessive, for a game where players can get wiped by the BBEG three hours in, and kicked into a bad ending as a reward.

Legend of The Dragoon

Monologuing Villains Ruin The Mood

Legend of The Dragoon is a prime example of what a JRPG should be. It's got colorful characters, tragedy, a rampaging evil lord, and Super-sentai/dragon-inspired powers. That's a recipe for a cool mixture of Japanese narrative goodness.

Sadly, the worst mood-killers in this game are the villains. They seem addicted to never-ending speeches, where scrolling dialogue takes over the screen for hours. Players are ready to kick the villains out of reality with their hard-earned Dragoon powers, but no, they need to wait until the villain finishes his speech. The original PS1 game had four discs, and is one of the longest JRPGs ever created.

Octopath Traveler

A Masterpiece With Way Too Much To Do

Octopath Traveler is one of the best things that has happened to the JRPG genre in the past few years. It was created in Unreal Engine, but designed to look like a classic isometric JRPG, with some cool 2D/3D details.

But going the infinite amount of content in this game can be overwhelming. There is not just one path to follow, but eight, hence the game’s title. With nothing but wits and the travelers' abilitie, it does tend to get convoluted. The game's main plot is diluted by the cross-country adventure gameplay. It's not for those who seek the goal, but it's great for those who enjoy the journey.

The Last Remnant

A Worthy But Over-Extended Heir Of The Final Fantasy Spirit

The Last Remnant has become a cult game already. Among the fans of the JRPG genre, its name echoes in the hall of fame of the longest games ever made. Though, after dozens of hours of gameplay, players begin to wonder: where is this going?

Its plot can be hard to understand at first, and its characters are a little bit cliché. However, its gameplay, design, and aesthetics are undeniably cool. Players can quickly get addicted. And since it's worth playing more than once, it is bound to be time-consuming.

Final Fantasy 12

So Many Classes To Try & Things To Kill

Having played all Final Fantasy games, one could expect to step into the world of Final Fantasy 12 ready to get more of the same good-old-fashioned turn-based goodness. Instead, FFXII brought a new combat engine, with an intricate class system that can provide hours of fun.

The hunt-quest system, guild rewards, and unlocking all the classes can potentially divert players from the main plot. This is both good and bad at the same time. Some fans of this game might adore this game for what it is: a fresh start for a stale formula. However, this game can be a time trap. It could take hundreds of hours to beat for those who jump into it unprepared.

The Legend Of Heroes: Trails Of Cold Steel 4

Dialogue, Scrolling Text, More Dialogue, & Chatty Characters

Legends Of Heroes: Trails Of Cold Steel 4 is a game for players who enjoy allegiance shifts, betrayal, and long monologues. With hundreds of dialogue lines between boss fights, and character drama to boot, this game has enough reflective content for a dissertation about the human condition. For some, it might feel unnatural to extend an otherwise harmonious plot into an amalgam of pop-up events and chatty teens trying to make themselves “understood” in a cruel society. But players who enjoy a deep, dramatic plot will find a treat in this game.

LOH: Trails Of Cold Steel 4 has a lot of playable characters (39 to be exact) and several endings to unlock. For those who manage to pull through thousands of dialogue lines, it's a great game. It's time-consuming, and some may find the writing cliché; however, it has a great visual design, and its tremendously enjoyable gameplay can trap players for hours once they get into it.

Persona 5

Persona's Not Such A Fast-Paced Franchise

From the legendary acclaimed series Persona comes the fifth title in the franchise, ready to twist players' inner worlds and set them on the right path. Persona 5 follows a group of troubled teenagers, trying to fix the damaged world that subjects them to a meaningless and oppressive life.

By using otherworldly powers to reform and dominate the minds of evildoers, they attempt to set themselves free from an oppressive, mind-controlling society. Fans love its side-quests and deep psychological drama. However, not everyone loves how this game forces players to complete scenarios while pressed by a deadline. If the heroes don’t complete the arcs in time, they get an immediate Game Over. As it's not a game that can be enjoyed at its fullest in only one playthrough, players need to put in hundreds of hours to see all that Persona 5 has to offer.
